p: The CCR5- Δ32 allele is mainly present in Europeans (10% on average) and the allele frequency exhibits a north-south cline with frequencies ranging from 16% in Northern Europe to 4% or less in Greece and in most of the Mediterranean islands (Figure 1A and [ 4, 5]). The broadest area of high frequency is located in North-Eastern Europe, particularly in the Baltic and White Sea regions. From these maximum, the frequency gradually decreases in all directions across Europe [ 4]; however, some additional peaks of frequency are found in France or Russian areas [ 4, 6- 8]. Moreover, Ashkenazi Jews have high frequencies of CCR5-Δ32, but this is likely due to founder effects unique to their history rather than the general process of dispersal that spread the allele in other populations [ 9]. Outside Europe, the mutation can be found at low frequencies in neighbouring regions (North Africa, Middle East, Central Asia); it is absent in Sub-Saharan Africa, East and South-East Asia and in indigenous populations of America and Oceania (Figure 1A).
